Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Impact of Large Scale Greenland Ice Sheet Melting on Glacier Hydrology and Meltwater Geochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration: In 2012, multiple lines of evidence suggest a record release of freshwater from the Greenland ice sheet (GrIS), the largest expanse of glacial ice in the Northern Hemisphere and a major source of meltwater and associated material to the surrounding North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans. Between July 8 and 12, satellite-derived estimates of surface melt increased from 40% to 97% of the ice sheet. This warming received widespread media attention and public interest, yet the scientific community lacks direct observations of meltwater controls on ice sheet movement and meltwater geochemistry for such a large-scale melting event. The overarching goal of this RAPID proposal is to quantify, in short order, the impact of a large-scale melting event on the ice sheet dynamics and meltwater biogeochemistry of a large, land-terminating glacier on the western Greenland margin. RAPID funds will enable the analysis and synthesis of a unique sample set collected during other fieldwork from the Leverett Glacier catchment, a large outlet glacier that discharges through a single proglacial river. Though the focus is on the 2012 episode, the investigators will also analyze samples and GrIS dynamics data from two field seasons (2011- 12), which will aid in interpretation of changes driven by the historic melting event owing to the highly contrasting annual freshwater discharge rates. The investigators will use time-series radiogenic (beryllium-7 and radon-222) and stable isotopes (oxygen and hydrogen), each with unique sources and constant production rates, from the Leverett glacier watershed to differentiate the fractions of meltwater sourced from recent surface snow, glacial ice and delayed flow meltwater. They will also investigate the composition and magnitude of nutrient and metal fluxes released from the subglacial environment and study how these fluxes evolved during July 2012. From 2011-12, parallel ice sheet geophysical data (GPS, satellite imagery) and meltwater biogeochemistry samples (carbon, macro- and micro-nutrients) have been collected by the PI and colleagues from universities in the United Kingdom. The proposed project will fully fund a Ph.D. student, and high school students and undergraduate interns will be recruited to assist with the laboratory aspect of the research. In order to increase the visibility of this project among the general public, the PI and student will co-author an article for the WHOI magazine Oceanus. This publication reaches a wide audience through both print- and web-based editions. Finally, the Ph.D. student will continue to report on the results of this study via an Expedition Blog called ?Following the Ice? on Scientific American (http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/expeditions/tag/following-the-ice/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each spring and summer, meltwater forms on the surface of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS) where it may escape through moulins, deep holes in the ice that penetrate to the ice bed. From there, the water travels to the ice sheet’s edge through a drainage system composed of groundwater aquifers, open cavities, and large cylindrical channels. How meltwater is partitioned between channels, groundwater, and cavities, and how the drainage system evolves each year is thought to control everything from the chemical load of the meltwater to the speed the ice sheet travels downhill. To answer questions related to the stability of the GrIS and its influence on ocean circulation and biogeochemistry, it is essential to understand the dynamics of these drainage networks.

One way to predict the ice sheet’s future behavior is to compare exceptionally warm years with cold years. Our study began in 2011, a cool year relative to the last decade, and continued into 2012, an especially warm year that included the largest single melting event of the GrIS since 1889. Our fieldwork took place at Leverett Glacier, a large land locked glacier in west Greenland that forms a lobe off the GrIS (Figure 1). With collaborators from the Universities of Bristol and Edinburgh, our work at Leverett included monitoring ice motion and air temperature with an array of GPS stations on the ice sheet surface. In the large river exiting Leverett Glacier we deployed chemical sensors for real-time measurement and collected water samples to for later analysis in the laboratory.

What made our study unique was that we made continuous radon measurements in the river exiting the GrIS. Every hour for 80 days, we measured radon concentrations from early spring melt through maximum runoff in midsummer. Similar to how radon gas can build up in one’s basement, radon also accumulates beneath the GrIS. Meltwater traveling through sediment and rock acquires radon and the more time it spends in contact with sediment and rocks, the higher the radon concentrations become.

While our first hypothesis was that we could use radon to search for pulses of meltwater previously stored at the ice bed, additional laboratory experiments revealed something surprising. Groundwater traveling beneath the ice was responsible for >90% of the radon measured in the river. This was exciting not only because groundwater generally contains the most chemical constituents, but also because groundwater flow through sediment beneath glaciers can cause sediments to deform and the glacier to move downhill. After we determined the likely concentration of radon in the groundwater beneath the ice sheet, we back calculated the volume of the river composed of groundwater.

We found that groundwater discharge underwent daily cycles of high and low volume that were periodically overwhelmed by large groundwater outbursts lasting several days. Of the meltwater that forms on the ice sheet’s surface, 99% travels through and under the GrIS via large open channels, while only 1% moves through subglacial aquifers. Despite the relatively small groundwater fraction, when we compared groundwater fluxes with records of temperature and ice motion, we found some striking correlations. During warm periods, more meltwater moves to the ice bed, which pressurizes the channels forcing water into the aquifer. We hypothesize that groundwater flow through sediments causes sediments to deform and the glacier to move faster. Once temperatures cool and meltwater inputs slow, channels de-pressurize and release the stored groundwater. We observed this cycle on a daily basis as well as on a several day cycle of ice motion followed by groundwater discharge. Prior to this work, the significance of groundwater in modulating ice motion of the GrIS was generally not considered.
